Was a strange experience being on the other end of the life lecture but I felt glad he could be so positive and obviously that was how he wanted me to be so.... Take it one day at a time.. Trite but true..

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 04:27AM IngridJ wrote: Hi all from Melbourne, Australia.. A valuable discussion for me... Have been reading with interest all your posts.You all sound amazing.... I am awaiting oncotype at the moment for 5mm idc. tumour highly er and pr pos. The Initial path reports made chemo look highly unlikely, but final report showed ki67 was borderline high at 20, and mitotic rate was 3/3, so the onc suggested oncotype as some small tumours can be aggressive. Felt so lucky to get it when I did but now having nervous anxiety about it all.. Just still not sure if size is factored into the oncotype score? Read somewhere that it was, and somewhere else that it wasn't.... Any clues??
Posts.Title: <1 cm - Stage 1a - Team 4My3kids rosecal954

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2013 05:52AM IngridJ wrote: Hi I was/am in a similar situation to you. Small grade two tumour, no nodes, found early.. All good.. But the oncotype came back one below intermediate, the tumour had borderline high ki67, and mitotic rate was 3/3; I was told no chemo by one onc, and yes, no, maybe by another. Age 43 at diagnosis.. So have opted for 4 x CT.. Hasn't been fun, but it hasn't been too bad either; have another two to go. Basically a month more.. I feel your pain... in the beginning it all seems so good.. But then the bit that isn't so good trickles in and you think hmmmm... For me, it came down to wanting to do everything to reduce future risk..... Am a thinker so knew it woukd play on my mind also.. Am not convinced it was completely necessary (the chemo), but then...it is all unknown... Good luck w your decision, hope the oncotype is low, low, low... From my observations, it is grade two that can have the widest variability in oncotype scores. Generally grade one tumours are low and three high, (although there are the exceptions), but grade two can seem to go either way...
Posts.Title: Stage 1, Node neg. has unique dilemmas Power-House IngridJ

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2013 11:38AM IngridJ wrote: You're welcome Power-House! Remember knowledge IS power, so gather all that you can re your situation... Makes it easier to make a decision when all of the facts are in front of you.. The other thing to remember is that you can get more than one oncologist's opinion. Two or even three.. I found following the threads on here about oncotype scores and other women's decisions very helpful. Type oncotype into the search and see what comes up. There is an oncotype roll call thread, and many, many threads to look at...There are some really detailed threads.. I found much more information from these boards than from my oncologist, as you'll learn I think that's fairly common. I remember stressing more over the oncotype results than anything- to be presented with a number, like a score in a competition.... Seemed (still does really) so freaky.. But because I'd done enough looking into how they arrive at the score, I was pretty sure I'd be in the grey zone.. And i was almost right...Not quite, but close enough to it... Check out the Tailorx trial which is going on at the moment, the upper end of the low range and the intermediate are being tested to ensure the right people are getting chemo. I think it's more to test over treatment than under treatment but its interesting. Also see if you can get the ki67 and the different components of the tumour's grade. I was told that the mototic rate was the one to look at.. Cancer math and predict are interesting tools to help....All in all, good luck and happy to help...:))
Posts.Title: Stage 1, Node neg. has unique dilemmas Power-House IngridJ

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 11:33PM IngridJ wrote: Hi Terrican My mother had bc too, but because she wasn't diagnosed until 68, I and my GP, thought no need to worry until in my 50's anyway.. However...Found a small idc in March, grade two, was on the fence re chemo (oncotype just below intermediate) am age 43, but am doing the 4xTC that you have been suggested. Have my third tomorrow.. It hasn't been too bad. Definitely doable so far.. As Flanelette says its insurance, and this is the chance to throw everything at it... I chose to have mastectomy on that ca side, turns out was the right choice as I also had two types of ca insitu.. Even if id opted for lumpectomy, would have been back having mas... Once chemo is done, will have the other side (mas) and recon, the mastectomy op not too bad.. Alleviates some of the future worry.. So fwiw- that's my story. It is your decision, and yes, can relate to all your thought processes, the freaked outedness etc...the whole thing..... Keep your sense of humour... Bite me comment made me lol..:)) Plus....Who could eat and do all that stuff with kids to look after??? Also- I haven't done the genetic testing yet.. Unlikely to be BRAC but maybe some genetic connection not yet fully identified.. That's poss, and my father had prostate so there is a link there possibly too.. Sigh...
Posts.Title: Stage 1, Node neg. has unique dilemmas Power-House IngridJ

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 11:37PM IngridJ wrote: PS if you do do chemo think about cold caps, there is a thread on these boards.. That has been my only regret....:(
